p.s: As already said, in the first two quatrains it is asked how summer could be able to survive the strong and powerful, but duo destroying winter.

In line one, Shakespeare uses an enumeration of powerful things, like stone or the sea to show that it doesn't matter how bug, how powerful or how many things there are, winter is able to destroy all of them.
At the end of this line is also an enjambment, to show how even those usually immortal things get destroyed by the winter.
Also the rhyme sea to mortality, which normally does not fit into Shakespeare's rhyme scheme underlines the weakness of the sea against winter.
In line 5 it continues with a metaphor.
The summer's honey breath is used metaphorically to describe the good weather, the warm days and the beautiful warm breezes, that are similar to the breath of a human.
So it is a personification too.
It is followed by another emjambment, to get into the fight between summer and winter.
Shakespeare calls it a siege (l. 6), which is a metaphor for the process of winter taking over the weather and opressingoppressing summer.
this process is described by another metaphor.
It is called the batt'ring days (l. 6).
This shows that Shakespeare describes the change of seasons as a fight.
The weapons of winter or cold days and snow, that destroy the nature.
These cold days are the batt'ring days.
You can find another metaphor in line ten.
Here, Shakespeare wrote time's best jewel, to once again describe how beautiful summer is, and that every person loves it, because also every person loves jewels.
They are a symbol for being wealthy.
Of course Shakespeare didn't just write about a change from summer to winter.
You need to transfer it to the time when he lived and what was going around in Britain at this time.
The Elizabethan time with the dark lady Queen Elizabeth was taking over.
So you can clearly say, in this sonnet the Elizabethan time is winter and the time before that is summer.

But but you can also also see, that Shakespeare hopes for a better time after the Elizabethan time, or is looking towards it, because you're right, that summer could hide sandlerg (l. 10), let it can come out again later, if winter gets weaker or so.
He doesn't believe that summer, or the time before Queen Elizabeth, can't come back.

But even even if it wouldn't come back, and line fourteen he wrote that all the love, so all the good memories he has from the time before the Elizabethan time, will be found in his texts or his sonnets.
He even comes back to the symbol of the sun, because he wrote that the love would still shine in his sonnets, just like the sun did it before winter came.
And you can see the sun shines until today because we can still learn from his sonnets how it was in the time he lived in.
